wikitext.*:
'''Rôs''' was the name of a promontory in the [[Great Lands]], according to the early version of the [[legendarium]] in some of the outlines for the continuation of ''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]''.<ref name="Ros">{{LT2|VI}}, p. 283</ref>

It was the place of the great [[Battle of Rôs]] during the [[Faring Forth]], in which the [[Elves]] were defeated.<ref name="Ros"/> While the precise location of the promontory is unknown, [[Christopher Tolkien]] suggests that it might be identified with [[wikipedia:Brittany|Brittany]], a peninsula and region in modern day [[wikipedia:France|France]].<ref>{{LT2|VI}}, p. 285</ref>

There is evidence that the [[Gnomes]] living there possessed their own unique dialect.<ref name="Roos">{{PE|11}}, p. 6</ref>

== Etymology ==
The name ''Rôs'' is in [[Gnomish]]. The ''[[Gnomish Lexicon]]'' glosses it as "the Sea; the all-embracing, the surrounding", with its [[Qenya]] cognate being '''''Rása'''''.<ref>{{PE|11}}, p. 65</ref> However, it seems that this meaning of the name is another, different one from that mentioned in the main section of the article above.<ref>{{LT2|Appendix}}, p. 347</ref>

Another possible origin of the name ''Rôs'', might lie in the village of [[wikipedia:Roos|Roos]] in [[wikipedia:Yorkshire|Yorkshire]], near which [[Tolkien]] was stationed in [[1917]]-[[1918]].<ref name="Roos"/>

The name '''''Roos''''' probably means either "moor" or "promontory" - with its [[Welsh]], [[wikipedia:Breton language|Breton]] and [[wikipedia:Irish language|Irish]] cognates being ''rhôs'' ("moor, heath, plain"), ''ros'' ("hillock") and ''ros'' ("promontory"), respectively.<ref name="Roos"/>

== Other versions of the legendarium ==
In other, later outlines, Rôs was either the name of the [[Kortirion#Other versions of the legendarium|capital]] of the Elves of [[Tol Eressëa]], or perhaps a name for Tol Eressëa itself.<ref>{{LT2|VI}}, p. 302</ref>
